No One Left Behind: Real-World Federated Class-Incremental Learning

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a hot collaborative training framework via aggregating model parameters of decentralized local clients. However, most FL methods unreasonably assume data categories of FL framework are known and fixed in advance. Moreover, some new local clients that collect novel categories unseen by other clients may be introduced to FL training irregularly. These issues render global model to undergo catastrophic forgetting on old categories, when local clients receive new categories consecutively under limited memory of storing old categories. To tackle the above issues, we propose a novel Local-Global Anti-forgetting (LGA) model. It ensures no local clients are left behind as they learn new classes continually, by addressing local and global catastrophic forgetting. Specifically, considering tackling class imbalance of local client to surmount local forgetting, we develop a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss and a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss. They can balance heterogeneous forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories, while ensure consistent class-relations within different tasks. Moreover, a proxy server is designed to tackle global forgetting caused by Non-IID class imbalance between different clients. It augments perturbed prototype images of new categories collected from local clients via self-supervised prototype augmentation, thus improving robustness to choose the best old global model for local-side semantic distillation loss. Experiments on representative datasets verify superior performance of our model against comparison methods. The code is available at https://github.com/JiahuaDong/LGA.

Index Terms:
Federated Learning, Class-Incremental Learning, Catastrophic Forgetting, Class Imbalance, Privacy Preservation.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) [31, 38, 19, 43] has attracted growing interests in enabling collaborative training across multiple decentralized local clients while providing privacy preservation. Without thoroughly compromising privacy protection of local clients [13, 35], it improves the performance of training data-hungry machine learning frameworks via aggregating decentralized local models that are learned on privately-accessible local data [2]. Meanwhile, it effectively tackles the data island problem in the real-world [46] via cooperatively training a global model. Until now, federated learning (FL) [57, 54, 25] has been successfully applied to a large number of research fields, such as mobile phones [36], medical diagnosis [27], intelligent robotics [52], wearable devices [32] and autonomous driving [39].

However, most existing federated learning (FL) models [48, 3, 43, 35, 29] unrealistically assume that the overall FL framework is trained in static application scenarios, where the learned data categories are fixed over time. Obviously, these methods [48, 43] cannot be successfully applied to dynamic real-world applications, in which the data of new categories from local clients arrives consecutively under a streaming manner. To tackle this setting, existing FL models [35, 43] require local clients to store all training data of old categories via high cost of memory storage, and then retrain local models to obtain a global class-incremental model via large computation overhead. Unfortunately, it may render the training of FL to be impracticable [36, 32] when local clients receive a large number of new categories continuously. Besides, if these models [36, 43, 32] are required to identify new categories incrementally with limited memory storage to store the training data of old categories, their performance on previously-learned old categories may decrease significantly (i.e., catastrophic forgetting on old categories [37, 10]). Moreover, some new additional local clients that receive the data of new categories unseen by other local clients may join in the FL training irregularly in real-world applications. The catastrophic forgetting on old categories can be further aggravated by these newly added local clients when training global model via the existing FL framework [57, 2].

To tackle above-mentioned practical scenarios [10], in this paper, we consider a real-world challenging FL problem, which is referred to as Federated Class-Incremental Learning (FCIL). Specifically, for the settings of FCIL, local clients receive the data of new categories incrementally in a streaming manner, and some newly-added local clients collecting unseen novel categories can be introduced to the overall FL training irregularly. More importantly, the current and newly-added local clients have their own preference to receive new categories in an online manner, indicating that class distributions across different local clients are non-independent and identically distributed (Non-IID). These local clients with limited memory available to store training data of old categories [37, 18, 53, 12] are required to learn a global class-incremental model collaboratively. This global model can identify new classes continuously under privacy preservation of local clients. Although some local clients only collect a small subset of new categories and store a small subset of old classes, all local clients are required to identify all seen categories, including both old and new classes. In the FCIL settings, no one is left behind when local clients learn new categories consecutively and address forgetting on old classes via collaborative FL training [2].

In this paper, as shown in Fig.¬†1, we use pandemic COVID-19 diagnosis [4] as a practical example to better understand the real-world FCIL problem. There are hundreds of hospitals and clinics to learn a global disease diagnosis model collaboratively via the FL training framework [43], before the pandemic outbreaks. When these hospitals and clinics receive new medical data related to COVID-19, they consider them as new disease category to perform typical FL training [57]. Besides, some new hospitals without storing the medical data of old infectious diseases but with collected COVID-19 data may participate in the fight against COVID-19. In the FCIL, all hospitals and clinics cannot be left behind, when they learn to diagnose new COVID-19 variants continuously while alleviate catastrophic forgetting on the old diseases. In this case, existing FL models [19, 43] suffer from large performance degradation on old diseases when collecting new COVID-19 variants continuously [4].

To identify new categories consecutively in the FCIL (e.g., diagnosing new COVID-19 variants), a trivial solution is to simply integrate class-incremental learning (CIL) [9, 20] and FL [2, 32] together. However, it requires global server to have strong prior knowledge about privacy-sensitive information of local clients (i.e., where and when to collect new categories), which heavily compromises privacy preservation in the FL. Moreover, in the FCIL, this solution suffers from local and global catastrophic forgetting on old categories:

  • ‚Ä¢

    Local catastrophic forgetting is brought by the class imbalance between old and new categories in each local client. Existing CIL methods [37, 42, 12] neglect the large heterogeneity of forgetting speeds among easy-to-forget and hard-to-forget classes within different tasks, which cannot address local forgetting on old categories.

  • ‚Ä¢

    Global catastrophic forgetting indicates the heterogeneous forgetting speeds among different local clients, which is caused by Non-IID class imbalance across local clients. This naive integration solution cannot balance heterogeneous forgetting on old classes among different local clients, further aggravating the local forgetting [10].

To address local and global forgetting in the FCIL, in this paper, we develop a novel Local-Global Anti-forgetting (LGA) model, which is a pioneering exploration to tackle the real-world FCIL problem under the privacy preservation. To be specific, we propose a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss to overcome local catastrophic forgetting on old categories. It can balance different forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories, while normalize the learning speeds of new classes. Besides, a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss is designed to ensure intrinsic category-relation consistency within different incremental tasks. This loss considers tackling heterogeneous forgetting speeds of old classes when performing semantic relation distillation. Moreover, considering Non-IID class imbalance across clients, we develop a proxy server to surmount global catastrophic forgetting. It significantly improves the distillation gain of the category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss at local side via providing the best old global model from a global perspective. For privacy preservation, we propose a prototype gradient communication strategy to transmit perturbed prototype images of new categories from local clients to proxy server. The proxy server reconstructs these perturbed images and augments them via self-supervised prototype augmentation to pick the best old global model for semantic distillation.

Experiments on representative datasets show significant performance improvements and effectiveness of the proposed LGA model, compared with baseline methods. Several core contributions of this work are summarized as follows:

  • ‚Ä¢

    We propose a real-world challenging FL problem referred to as Federated Class-Incremental Learning (FCIL), where two major challenges are local catastrophic forgetting brought by local clients‚Äô class imbalance and global catastrophic forgetting brought by Non-IID class imbalance among different local clients.

  • ‚Ä¢

    A novel Local-Global Anti-forgetting (LGA) model is proposed to address FCIL problem via surmounting local and global catastrophic forgetting on old categories. To our best knowledge, our model is the first work to identify new categories consecutively in the FL field.

  • ‚Ä¢

    We tackle local forgetting via developing a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss and a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss. They can balance heterogeneous forgetting of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old classes, while distill category-relations consistency among different incremental tasks.

  • ‚Ä¢

    A proxy server is designed to collect perturbed prototype images of new classes under privacy preservation via prototype gradient communication. It augments these images via self-supervised prototype augmentation to select the best old model for global anti-forgetting.

This paper is a significant extension of our conference work [10]. Compared with [10], some substantial improvements of this work are listed as follows: 1) We propose a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss to balance heterogeneous forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old classes via adaptively reweighting category-imbalanced gradient propagation. 2) We design a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss to distill category-relations consistency among different incremental tasks via considering heterogeneous forgetting speeds of old categories. 3) We ameliorate the proxy server to augment perturbed prototype images via self-supervised prototype augmentation, which can accurately select the best old global model to achieve global anti-forgetting. 4) A large number of qualitative comparison experiments under various FCIL settings and evaluation metrics are conducted on benchmark datasets to further illustrate the effectiveness of our LGA model against baseline comparison methods. 5) More visualization results, ablation studies and insightful analyses are introduced to draw important conclusions.

2 Related Work

2.1 Federated Learning

For privacy protection of local clients, federated learning (FL) [60, 47, 54, 25] focuses on training a decentralized global model via aggregating network parameters of different local models. After McMahan et al. [31] propose an average-weighting strategy to aggregate multiple local models when learning global model collaboratively, [38] develops a FedProx framework to address the data heterogeneity for federated local models. Furthermore, [43] encourages local models to learn a shared optimum via introducing a penalty regularizer into objective function. To minimize communication overhead in federated learning, Chen et al. [2] design a temporal aggregation mechanism via synchronous learning. They aggregate deeper layers in the last few iterations, but integrate shallow layers at every iteration. [57, 46] design a Bayesian non-parametric strategy to aggregate model parameters of local clients. Yoon et al. [56] propose federated continual learning (FCL) [59] via considering a series of continuous tasks within local clients, but they ignore that new local clients collecting novel categories unseen by other clients may be introduced to FL framework. Besides, [56] assumes all tasks have the same and fixed class number, while it has strong prior knowledge about task indices for testing. It is significantly different from FCIL problem that can learn varying number of new classes in each task and classify all classes observed so far without prior knowledge about task indices. Peng et al. [33] rely on domain adaptation technology [7, 8] to improve the generalization performance on unsupervised target domain at local side under the FL settings. Qu et al. [35] address performance degradation of heterogeneous data across local clients when deploying the FL model on different devices with large distribution shift. However, above FL methods [57, 2, 46] cannot learn new categories consecutively in a streaming manner, and suffer from forgetting on old categories when local memory is limited to store old categories.

2.2 Class-Incremental Learning

Class-incremental learning (CIL) [55, 21, 14, 17] focuses on identifying new categories continuously in the real-world. We divide the existing CIL methods [11, 62, 30] into three categories: learning without access to training data of old classes, generative replay of old classes and exemplar memory construction of old classes. Specifically, when the training data of old classes is unavailable, Kirkpatrick et al. [22] propose to compensate biased optimization brought by new classes, and knowledge distillation is employed by [26, 42, 58] to tackle performance degradation (i.e., catastrophic forgetting) on old categories. For the generative replay of old classes, [49] relies on adversarial learning to design memory replay generator of old classes, and surmounts catastrophic forgetting via performing replay alignment. Besides, [41] proposes a dual cooperative model including a memory generator to synthesize old classes and a task solver to address forgetting. As introduced in [37, 51, 11], class-imbalanced distribution between old and new categories is main reason for exemplar memory-based CIL methods [44, 12] to suffer from catastrophic forgetting. To be specific, [16] considers distilling causal relations of class-imbalanced training samples. Simon et al. [44] propose an improved knowledge distillation technology, and utilize geodesic path to measure the similarity between old and new predictions. [40, 28, 18] design an adaptive network to balance the stability and plasticity. [12] introduces transformer framework to tackle forgetting on old classes via designing expandable task tokens. However, to tackle the FCIL problem, these existing CIL methods [37, 12] require strong privacy knowledge about where and when to collect new classes, which is impracticable to violate the requirement of privacy preservation in real-world applications.

4 The Proposed Model

The graphical illustration of proposed LGA model is presented in Fig.¬†2. To tackle the FCIL problem, our LGA model performs local anti-forgetting (Section¬†4.1) via a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss and a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss, while achieving global anti-forgetting (Section¬†4.2) via proxy server to improve local distillation gain from a global perspective.

4.1 Local Anti-Forgetting

The lùëôl-th local client ùíÆl‚ààùíµnsubscriptùíÆùëôsubscriptùíµùëõ\mathcal{S}_{l}\in\mathcal{Z}_{n} with privately accessible exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} can receive new training data ùíØltsuperscriptsubscriptùíØùëôùë°\mathcal{T}_{l}^{t} in the tùë°t-th incremental task. Given a mini-batch {ùêól‚Äãbt,ùêòl‚Äãbt}={ùê±l‚Äãit,ùê≤l‚Äãit}i=1B‚äÇùíØlt‚à™‚Ñ≥lsuperscriptsubscriptùêóùëôùëèùë°superscriptsubscriptùêòùëôùëèùë°superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°ùëñ1ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùíØùëôùë°subscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\{\mathbf{X}_{lb}^{t},\mathbf{Y}_{lb}^{t}\}=\{\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}\}_{i=1}^{B}\subset\mathcal{T}_{l}^{t}\cup\mathcal{M}_{l}, the classification loss ‚ÑíCEsubscript‚ÑíCE\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}} for the lùëôl-th client ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} is defined as follows:

‚ÑíCE=1B‚Äã‚àëi=1BùíüCE‚Äã(Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãit,Œòr,t),ùê≤l‚Äãit),subscript‚ÑíCE1ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêµsubscriptùíüCEsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptŒòùëüùë°superscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}}=\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{CE}}(P_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\Theta^{r,t}),\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}), (1)

where Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t} represents the global classification model in the tùë°t-th incremental task, and its model parameters are distributed from global server ùíÆgsubscriptùíÆùëî\mathcal{S}_{g} to local clients at the rùëür-th global round. Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãit,Œòr,t)‚àà‚ÑùCo+CtsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptŒòùëüùë°superscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùê∂ùëúsuperscriptùê∂ùë°P_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\Theta^{r,t})\in\mathbb{R}^{C^{o}+C^{t}} is the probability prediction of global model Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t}. BùêµB represents the batch size, and ùíüCE‚Äã(‚ãÖ,‚ãÖ)subscriptùíüCE‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{CE}}(\cdot,\cdot) denotes the standard cross-entropy loss.

However, the severe class imbalance between old and new categories (i.e., NltClt‚â´|‚Ñ≥l|Clomuch-greater-thansuperscriptsubscriptùëÅùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°subscript‚Ñ≥ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëú\frac{N_{l}^{t}}{C_{l}^{t}}\gg\frac{|\mathcal{M}_{l}|}{C_{l}^{o}}) in the lùëôl-th local client ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} enforces its local training (optimized via Eq.¬†(1)) to significantly decrease the performance on old categories. That is to say, ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} suffers from local catastrophic forgetting on old classes when minimizing Eq.¬†(1) for local model training. To achieve local anti-forgetting for local clients, we develop a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss to balance heterogeneous forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories, while propose a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss to distill consistent category relations within different incremental tasks.

‚àô‚àô\bullet Category-Balanced Gradient-Adaptive Compensation: When local client ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} receives global model Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t} from global server ùíÆgsubscriptùíÆùëî\mathcal{S}_{g} at the rùëür-th global round, the class imbalance within local client leads to gradient-imbalanced back-propagation of the classifier in Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t}. It enforces the training of local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} to suffer from various updating speeds for old and new categories (i.e., different forgetting speeds for old categories and different learning speeds for new categories). Such heterogeneous updating speeds among different classes significantly aggravate catastrophic forgetting on old classes, when new training data from continuous learning tasks becomes a subset of old learned categories consecutively.

To achieve this, Dong et al. [10] propose to reweight imbalanced gradient back-propagation of old and new categories. However, it normalizes heterogeneous forgetting speeds of all old categories via an unified gradient normalization mean instead of task-specific gradient means. Such strategy unreasonably assumes all old classes have the same forgetting speed, and neglects significant heterogeneity of forgetting speeds among old categories from different incremental tasks. Thus, the reweighting strategy in [10] enforces the model to bias towards some hard-to-forget categories learned in recent tasks, while ignoring other easy-to-forget categories from long-ago learned tasks. Besides, the hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories change dynamically as the consecutive learning tasks, further increasing the difficulty to balance heterogeneous forgetting of old categories.

To tackle the above challenges, as depicted in Fig.¬†2, we propose a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss ‚ÑíCBsubscript‚ÑíCB\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CB}}. It can balance heterogeneous forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories, while normalize learning speeds of new categories via considering category-level balance to adaptively reweight gradient back-propagation. It aggravates the difficulty of {ùí±Œ∫}Œ∫=1tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùí±ùúÖùúÖ1ùë°\{\mathcal{V}_{\kappa}\}_{\kappa=1}^{t} to evaluate the heterogeneity of forgetting speeds for different old classes, due to the noisy probability predictions brought by easy-to-forget old classes. Thus, Eq.¬†(3) is rewritten as:

ùí±Œ∫s=1‚àëi=1BùïÄùê≤l‚Äãit‚ààùí¥lŒ∫‚Äã‚àëi=1B|ùí±l‚Äãit|CloClo+Clt‚ãÖùïÄùê≤l‚Äãit‚ààùí¥lŒ∫.superscriptsubscriptùí±ùúÖùë†1superscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêµsubscriptùïÄsuperscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùí¥ùëôùúÖsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêµ‚ãÖsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùí±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°subscriptùïÄsuperscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùí¥ùëôùúÖ\displaystyle\mathcal{V}_{\kappa}^{s}=\frac{1}{\sum_{i=1}^{B}\mathbb{I}_{\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}\in\mathcal{Y}_{l}^{\kappa}}}\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{B}|\mathcal{V}_{li}^{t}|^{\frac{C_{l}^{o}}{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}}}\cdot\mathbb{I}_{\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}\in\mathcal{Y}_{l}^{\kappa}}. (4)

The sharper task-specific gradient means {ùí±Œ∫s}Œ∫=1tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùí±ùúÖùë†ùúÖ1ùë°\{\mathcal{V}_{\kappa}^{s}\}_{\kappa=1}^{t} obtained via Eq.¬†(4) are then utilized to reweight standard cross-entropy loss ‚ÑíCEsubscript‚ÑíCE\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}} and we formulate the category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss ‚ÑíCBsubscript‚ÑíCB\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CB}} as follows:

‚ÑíCB=1B‚Äã‚àëi=1B|ùí±l‚Äãit|CloClo+Clt‚àëŒ∫=1tùí±Œ∫s‚ãÖùïÄùê≤l‚Äãit‚ààùí¥lŒ∫‚ãÖùíüCE‚Äã(Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãit,Œòlr,t),ùê≤l‚Äãit),subscript‚ÑíCB1ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùëñ1ùêµ‚ãÖsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùí±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùúÖ1ùë°‚ãÖsuperscriptsubscriptùí±ùúÖùë†subscriptùïÄsuperscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùí¥ùëôùúÖsubscriptùíüCEsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°superscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°\displaystyle\!\!\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CB}}\!=\!\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{B}\frac{|\mathcal{V}_{li}^{t}|^{\frac{C_{l}^{o}}{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}}}}{\sum_{\kappa=1}^{t}\mathcal{V}_{\kappa}^{s}\cdot\mathbb{I}_{\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}\in\mathcal{Y}_{l}^{\kappa}}}\!\cdot\!\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{CE}}(P_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\Theta_{l}^{r,t}),\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}),\!\! Obviously, Eq.¬†(5) enforces the local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} to perform category-balanced gradient optimization adaptively, while addresses noisy predictions on easy-to-forget old categories via the sharper task-specific gradient means {ùí±Œ∫s}Œ∫=1tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùí±ùúÖùë†ùúÖ1ùë°\{\mathcal{V}_{\kappa}^{s}\}_{\kappa=1}^{t}.

‚àô‚àô\bullet Category Gradient-Induced Semantic Distillation: After we initialize the local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} of ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} via the current global model Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t} at the rùëür-th global round, the probability predicted via Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} reflects semantic affinity among different categories during local training. In the FCIL, such semantic similarity relations between old and new categories are essential to address local catastrophic forgetting on hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old classes. Thus, we propose a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} to explore category-semantic relation consistency across incremental tasks via considering category-balanced gradient propagation among new classes, hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old classes. As shown in Fig.¬†2, we feed a mini-batch {ùê±l‚Äãit,ùê≤l‚Äãit}i=1B‚äÇùíØlt‚à™‚Ñ≥lsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôùëñùë°ùëñ1ùêµsuperscriptsubscriptùíØùëôùë°subscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\{\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\mathbf{y}_{li}^{t}\}_{i=1}^{B}\subset\mathcal{T}_{l}^{t}\cup\mathcal{M}_{l} into old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} and current local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t}, to predict the probabilities Plt‚àí1‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãit,Œòlt‚àí1)‚àà‚ÑùCosuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°1superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1superscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùê∂ùëúP_{l}^{t-1}(\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\Theta_{l}^{t-1})\in\mathbb{R}^{C^{o}} of old categories and Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãit,Œòlr,t)‚àà‚ÑùCo+CtsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°superscript‚Ñùsuperscriptùê∂ùëúsuperscriptùê∂ùë°P_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\Theta_{l}^{r,t})\in\mathbb{R}^{C^{o}+C^{t}} of old and new categories. Obviously, the probabilities predicted by Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} and Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} indicate underlying semantic consistency of inter-class relations across different tasks. The proposed ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} can distill such intrinsic semantic consistency from old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} learned at the (t‚àí1)ùë°1(t\!-\!1)-th task to current local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t}, and reweight the relation distillation of different tasks for category-balanced gradient propagation.

In order to distill semantic knowledge of old categories from Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} into Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t}, existing distillation methods [1, 16, 6] only consider semantic consistency of old categories among Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} and Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t}. However, they neglect the intrinsic relation consistency between old and new categories. Besides, such semantic consistency of old categories can be significantly affected by the heterogeneous forgetting speeds of easy-to-forget and hard-to-forget old categories from different incremental tasks. To this end, the proposed loss ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} considers inter-class relations consistency within each incremental task, and reweights it via task-specific gradient means {ùí±Œ∫s}Œ∫=1tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùí±ùúÖùë†ùúÖ1ùë°\{\mathcal{V}_{\kappa}^{s}\}_{\kappa=1}^{t} to tackle heterogeneous forgetting speeds of old classes. ‚àô‚àô\bullet Task Transition Detection: In the FCIL settings, local clients are required to automatically identify when new classes arrive without prior knowledge. Then they can store old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} and update their exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} to train local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} via optimizing ‚Ñílocalsubscript‚Ñílocal\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{local}} in Eq.¬†(7). To this end, an intuitive strategy is to distinguish whether the categories of new training data have already been learned by the current local client. Unfortunately, it cannot identify whether the labels of new training data belong to the new categories or old categories seen by other local clients, due to the Non-IID class distribution across local clients in the FCIL. Besides, the sharp performance decrease is considered as an indicator for local clients to receive new classes. However, this strategy neglects the fact that Non-IID class distribution across local clients brought by random determination of {ùíµo,ùíµn,ùíµa}subscriptùíµùëúsubscriptùíµùëõsubscriptùíµùëé\{\mathcal{Z}_{o},\mathcal{Z}_{n},\mathcal{Z}_{a}\} can result in significant performance degradation, even though local clients have not collected new classes.

To address these issues, we develop a task transition detection strategy for local clients to automatically distinguish when to collect new classes. Given training data ùíØltsuperscriptsubscriptùíØùëôùë°\mathcal{T}_{l}^{t} of the tùë°t-th task, each local client uses global model Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t} (obtained from ùíÆgsubscriptùíÆùëî\mathcal{S}_{g} at the rùëür-th round) to compute average entropy ‚Ñãlr,tsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñãùëôùëüùë°\mathcal{H}_{l}^{r,t}:

‚Ñãlr,t=1Nlt‚Äã‚àëi=1Nlt‚Ñê‚Äã(Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãit,Œòr,t)),superscriptsubscript‚Ñãùëôùëüùë°1superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùëñ1superscriptsubscriptùëÅùëôùë°‚ÑêsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôùëñùë°superscriptŒòùëüùë°\mathcal{H}_{l}^{r,t}=\frac{1}{N_{l}^{t}}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{l}^{t}}\mathcal{I}(P_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{li}^{t},\Theta^{r,t})), (8)

where ‚Ñê‚Äã(ùê©)=‚àëiùê©i‚Äãlog‚Å°ùê©i‚Ñêùê©subscriptùëñsubscriptùê©ùëñsubscriptùê©ùëñ\mathcal{I}(\mathbf{p})=\sum_{i}\mathbf{p}_{i}\log\mathbf{p}_{i} denotes the entropy function. We argue that new categories are collected by local clients when there is a sudden rise for ‚Ñãlr,tsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñãùëôùëüùë°\mathcal{H}_{l}^{r,t} (i.e., ‚Ñãlr,t‚àí‚Ñãlr‚àí1,t‚â•resuperscriptsubscript‚Ñãùëôùëüùë°superscriptsubscript‚Ñãùëôùëü1ùë°subscriptùëüùëí\mathcal{H}_{l}^{r,t}-\mathcal{H}_{l}^{r-1,t}\geq r_{e}). resubscriptùëüùëír_{e} is set as 1.21.21.2 empirically in this paper. After identifying new categories, local client will store old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1}, and update the exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} and tùë°t via t‚Üêt+1‚Üêùë°ùë°1t\leftarrow t+1.

4.2 Global Anti-Forgetting

As aforementioned, class imbalance between old and new categories at local side causes local catastrophic forgetting on old categories, which can be effectively tackled via Eq.¬†(7). However, the heterogeneous local forgetting brought by Non-IID class imbalance among different local clients enforces the global model to suffer from global catastrophic forgetting on old categories. Such global forgetting will exacerbate local forgetting on old categories to a certain extent. As a result, we consider tackling heterogeneous local forgetting across different clients from a global perspective [10]. As introduced in Section¬†4.1, the proposed loss ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} in Eq.¬†(7) can distill inter-class semantic relations within each incremental task from the old classification model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} to current local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t}. Obviously, the relation distillation gain can be significantly improved via selecting a better old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} from a global perspective. Therefore, under local privacy preservation, the selection of best old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} from a global perspective is important to tackle heterogeneous local forgetting and achieve global anti-forgetting in the FCIL settings.

To this end, a trivial strategy is that each local client stores its own all old models when training local model in the tùë°t-th learning task. However, it only considers local data distribution to select Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} rather than a global perspective. Besides, it cannot ensure the selected Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} has the best performance to tackle global forgetting on all old categories, due to the Non-IID class distribution across different local clients (i.e., the label space ùí¥lt‚äÇùí¥tsuperscriptsubscriptùí¥ùëôùë°superscriptùí¥ùë°\mathcal{Y}_{l}^{t}\subset\mathcal{Y}^{t} of local client ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} is only a subset of ùí¥tsuperscriptùí¥ùë°\mathcal{Y}^{t} in the tùë°t-th task). Thus, as shown in Fig.¬†2, a proxy server ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} is developed to choose the best old model Œòt‚àí1superscriptŒòùë°1\Theta^{t-1} for all local clients from a global perspective, while it considers privacy preservation of local clients.

To be specific, at the start of the tùë°t-th incremental task, local clients first employ task transition detection strategy (proposed in Section¬†4.1) to identify whether new categories are received. Considering privacy preservation at local side, we propose a prototype gradient communication mechanism to transmit perturbed prototype gradients of new categories from local clients to proxy server ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p}, after local clients have identified new categories. ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} then uses these gradients collected from local clients to reconstruct perturbed prototype images of new categories, and augments them via a self-supervised prototype augmentation strategy. After that, it evaluates the performance of global model Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t} (obtained from ùíÆgsubscriptùíÆùëî\mathcal{S}_{g}) on these reconstructed perturbed images with representation augmentation to select the best one. When the best global model Œòr,tsuperscriptŒòùëüùë°\Theta^{r,t} is distributed from ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} to local clients, they consider it as the best old model to learn the next incremental task (t+1ùë°1t\!+\!1) via optimizing ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} in Eq.¬†(7).

‚àô‚àô\bullet Prototype Gradient Communication: When the lùëôl-th client ùíÆl‚ààùíµn‚à™ùíµasubscriptùíÆùëôsubscriptùíµùëõsubscriptùíµùëé\mathcal{S}_{l}\in\mathcal{Z}_{n}\cup\mathcal{Z}_{a} has identified new classes in the tùë°t-th task ùíØltsuperscriptsubscriptùíØùëôùë°\mathcal{T}_{l}^{t} via task transition detention, it selects only one representative prototype image ùê±l‚Äãc‚àótsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t} (c=Clo+1,‚ãØ,Clo+Cltùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëú1‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°c=C_{l}^{o}\!+\!1,\cdots,C_{l}^{o}\!+\!C_{l}^{t}) for each new category in ùíØltsuperscriptsubscriptùíØùëôùë°\mathcal{T}_{l}^{t}. Note that the representation of ùê±l‚Äãc‚àótsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t} is closest to the average feature of all images from the cùëêc-th category. The selected Cltsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°C_{l}^{t} prototype images and corresponding labels {ùê±l‚Äãc‚àót,ùê≤l‚Äãc‚àót}c=Clo+1Clo+Cltsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°superscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°ùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëú1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°\{\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t},\mathbf{y}_{lc^{*}}^{t}\}_{c={C_{l}^{o}+1}}^{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}} are forwarded into a gradient encoding network Œì={ùí≤i}i=1KŒìsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptùí≤ùëñùëñ1ùêæ\Gamma=\{\mathcal{W}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{K} with total KùêæK layers to obtain their gradients {‚àáŒìl‚Äãc}c=Clo+1Clo+Cltsuperscriptsubscript‚àásubscriptŒìùëôùëêùëêsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëú1superscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°\{\nabla\Gamma_{lc}\}_{c={C_{l}^{o}+1}}^{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}}, where ùí≤isubscriptùí≤ùëñ\mathcal{W}_{i} denotes the weights of iùëñi-th layer and we set K=4ùêæ4K=4 to reduce communication overhead. ‚àáùí≤iŒìl‚Äãc=‚àáùí≤iùíüCE‚Äã(Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãc‚àót,Œì),ùê≤l‚Äãc‚àót)subscript‚àásubscriptùí≤ùëñsubscriptŒìùëôùëêsubscript‚àásubscriptùí≤ùëñsubscriptùíüCEsuperscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°Œìsuperscriptsubscriptùê≤ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°\nabla_{\mathcal{W}_{i}}\Gamma_{lc}=\nabla_{\mathcal{W}_{i}}\mathcal{D}_{\mathrm{CE}}(P_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t},\Gamma),\mathbf{y}_{lc^{*}}^{t}) represents the iùëñi-th gradient element of ‚àáŒìl‚Äãc‚àásubscriptŒìùëôùëê\nabla\Gamma_{lc}, where Plt‚Äã(ùê±l‚Äãc‚àót,Œì)superscriptsubscriptùëÉùëôùë°superscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°ŒìP_{l}^{t}(\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t},\Gamma) denotes the predicted probability of ùê±l‚Äãc‚àótsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t}. Considering privacy protection, we introduce noisy perturbation to the latent feature space of prototype images. Œºùúá\mu is the learning rate to update ùê±l‚Äãc‚àótsuperscriptsubscriptùê±ùëôsuperscriptùëêùë°\mathbf{x}_{lc^{*}}^{t}.

Security Assumptions: We follow some mild assumptions that the proxy server is hosted by a trusted third party and is also responsible for initializing an encoding model ŒìŒì\Gamma before training FL framework. Our mechanism will not communicate ŒìŒì\Gamma during FL training, while each selected client uses its own channel to communicate gradients with the proxy server. There is no communication channel between clients, and the proxy server is required not to share received gradients to the global server or other parties. Moreover, all channels are reliable and protected by crypto protocols. With these assumptions, we believe that the proxy server is secure and hard to be attacked. Even if malicious attackers could compromise several selected clients and get ŒìŒì\Gamma, they cannot steal the gradients of other clients since the communication channels are separated. In the worst case, attackers could eavesdrop gradients in some ways, but they can only recover perturbed prototype exemplars (see Fig.¬†5), where the privacy of local clients is protected via our proposed mechanism.

4.3 Training Pipeline

As presented in Algorithm¬†1, we introduce the overall training pipeline of proposed LGA model. Specifically, when receiving training data of the first incremental task, all local clients update their private exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} via following iCaRL [37], and use their private data to compute the average entropy ‚Ñãlr,tsuperscriptsubscript‚Ñãùëôùëüùë°\mathcal{H}_{l}^{r,t} via Eq.¬†(8). In the FCIL, some local clients randomly selected by global server ùíÆgsubscriptùíÆùëî\mathcal{S}_{g} are required to perform local training at each global round. If these selected local clients have detected new categories via the task transition detection, they will generate perturbed prototype images belonging to new categories via optimizing Eq.¬†(14), and transmit these prototype gradients to ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} via prototype gradient communication strategy. Then ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} uses these prototype gradients received from local clients to reconstruct perturbed prototype images via Eq.¬†(10). The reconstructed images are augmented by ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} in the feature space, which are then employed to pick the best global model ŒòtsuperscriptŒòùë°\Theta^{t} until the next task. In the tùë°t-th (t‚â•2ùë°2t\geq 2) task, ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} distributes the best global models of the (t‚àí1)ùë°1(t\!-\!1)-th and tùë°t-th tasks (i.e., Œòt‚àí1superscriptŒòùë°1\Theta^{t-1} and ŒòtsuperscriptŒòùë°\Theta^{t}) to local client ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l}. If ùíÆlsubscriptùíÆùëô\mathcal{S}_{l} detects new categories via task transition detection, it regards ŒòtsuperscriptŒòùë°\Theta^{t} as the best old model Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} to perform local training via minimizing Eq.¬†(7); otherwise, Œòt‚àí1superscriptŒòùë°1\Theta^{t-1} is used as Œòlt‚àí1superscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùë°1\Theta_{l}^{t-1} to train local model Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t}. After that, all updated local models Œòlr,tsuperscriptsubscriptŒòùëôùëüùë°\Theta_{l}^{r,t} are collected by ùíÆgsubscriptùíÆùëî\mathcal{S}_{g} to aggregate them as global model Œòr+1,tsuperscriptŒòùëü1ùë°\Theta^{r+1,t} for the next round.

5 Experiments

5.1 Datasets and Evaluation Metrics

We introduce comparison experiments on CIFAR-100 [23], MiniImageNet [45], TinyImageNet [34] and ImageNet-1000 [5] datasets to illustrate the effectiveness of our LGA model.

CIFAR-100 [23] consists of 100 different categories with total 60,000 samples, where each category has 500 training samples and 100 test images, and the image size is 32√ó32323232\times 32. MiniImageNet [45] is composed of 100 categories that are generated from ImageNet [5]. The images of each category are split into a training set with 500 images and a test set with 100 images. TinyImageNet [34] consists of 100,000 samples from 200 categories. We assign 500 training images and 50 test images for each category, and downsize each image to 64√ó64646464\times 64. ImageNet-1000 [5] is a large-scale dataset including 1,00010001,000 categories. For each class, we use about 1,30013001,300 images for training and 50 images for testing.

Evaluation Metric: In this work, we utilize three kinds of metrics (i.e., top-1 accuracy, F1 score and recall) to show the superior performance of our proposed LGA model.

5.2 Implementation Details

In the FCIL settings, as introduced in [10], we follow the identical protocols proposed in [37, 51] to set a series of consecutive learning tasks for fair comparison experiments with some representative class-incremental learning (CIL) models [37, 51, 11, 16, 44, 1, 12, 18]. Specifically, we employ the same class order used in iCaRL [37], set T={5,10,20}ùëá51020T=\{5,10,20\} to perform different incremental tasks on benchmark datasets, and utilize the same classification backbone ResNet-18 [15] as local model. Following baseline iCaRL [37], we use the same strategies (i.e., random horizontal flip, color jitter, normalization and random cropping) for data augmentation. Besides, the mixup technology proposed in DyTox [12] is not used in this paper. We set the exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} as 2,00020002,000, and follow iCaRL [37] to update ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} as the incremental tasks. The buffer size of exemplar set ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} is fixed as new classes increase. For the cùëêc-th (c=1,‚ãØ,Clo+Cltùëê1‚ãØsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°c=1,\cdots,C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}) class, the lùëôl-th local client can store the top |‚Ñ≥l|Clo+Cltsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°\frac{|\mathcal{M}_{l}|}{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}} exemplars whose features are closest to the average embedding of all samples belonging to the cùëêc-th class. Thus, we store |‚Ñ≥l|Clo+Cltsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°\frac{|\mathcal{M}_{l}|}{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}} exemplars per new class and remove |‚Ñ≥l|Clo‚àí|‚Ñ≥l|Clo+Cltsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëôsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùëúsuperscriptsubscriptùê∂ùëôùë°\frac{|\mathcal{M}_{l}|}{C_{l}^{o}}-\frac{|\mathcal{M}_{l}|}{C_{l}^{o}+C_{l}^{t}} samples per old class in the tùë°t-th task.

All local models are optimized via the SGD optimizer with initial learning rate as 2.0. We consider a 4-layer LeNet [24] as the gradient encoding network ŒìŒì\Gamma in this paper. Moreover, local clients utilize a SGD optimizer to generate representative perturbed images, and proxy server employs a L-BFGS optimizer to reconstruct prototype images, where their learning rates are initialized as 1.01.01.0. In the first learning task, the number of local clients is set as 303030. As the consecutive learning tasks arrive, we add 101010 new local clients for each new task. In the FCIL settings, 101010 local clients are chosen to perform 202020-epoch local training at each global round. Considering Non-IID class imbalance across different local clients, we randomly assign 60%percent6060\% categories from the label space of current learning task to local clients for CIFAR-100 [23], MiniImageNet [45] and TinyImageNet [34], while we set 70%percent7070\% for ImageNet-1000 [5]. All experiment results shown in this paper are averaged over 3 random runs, where random seeds are set as {2021,2022,2023}202120222023\{2021,2022,2023\}.

5.3 Comparison Experiments

As shown in Tables¬†I‚àºsimilar-to\simVIII, we introduce a large number of comparison experiments between our model and other competing methods on CIFAR-100 [23], MiniImageNet [45], TinyImageNet [34] and ImageNet-1000 [5] datasets when setting the number of consecutive learning tasks as T={5,10,20}ùëá51020T=\{5,10,20\}. Avg. (%) is the averaged performance of different tasks, and Imp. (%) denotes the performance improvement of our model over other comparison methods. We have the following conclusions from the presented results in Tables¬†I‚àºsimilar-to\simVIII: 1) The proposed LGA model has significant performance improvements (2.9%‚àº10.5%similar-topercent2.9percent10.52.9\%\sim 10.5\% in terms of averaged accuracy) over our conference version (i.e., GLFC [10]), since the proposed category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss ‚ÑíCBsubscript‚ÑíCB\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CB}} and category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} can effectively perform local anti-forgetting on old classes. 2) When compared with other baseline class-incremental learning (CIL) methods [37, 51, 11, 16, 44, 1, 12, 18], our model outperforms them about 4.8%‚àº27.3%similar-topercent4.8percent27.34.8\%\sim 27.3\% averaged accuracy. It validates the effectiveness of the improved proxy server to perform global anti-forgetting on old classes via selecting the best old model from a global perspective. 3) When performing on different kinds of consecutive learning tasks (i.e., T={5,10,20}ùëá51020T=\{5,10,20\}), our LGA model has achieved state-of-the-art performance against other comparison methods, which illustrates the robustness and effectiveness of our LGA model to tackle local and global forgetting under different experimental settings in the FCIL.

5.4 Ablation Studies

This subsection shows ablation experiments to illustrate the effectiveness of each proposed module in our LGA model under different settings (i.e., T={5,10,20}ùëá51020T=\{5,10,20\}), as shown in Tables¬†I‚àºsimilar-to\simVIII. Ours-w/oCBL, Ours-w/oSDL and Ours-w/oPSR represent the performance of training proposed LGA model without utilizing the category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss ‚ÑíCBsubscript‚ÑíCB\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CB}} (CBL), category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} (SDL) and proxy server ùíÆpsubscriptùíÆùëù\mathcal{S}_{p} (PSR). Ours-w/oCBL and Ours-w/oSDL use cross-entropy loss ‚ÑíCEsubscript‚ÑíCE\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{CE}} and distillation loss proposed in iCaRL [37] for substitution. Ours-w/oPSR cannot use proxy server to choose the best old global model for global anti-forgetting, and it randomly selects an old global model for semantic distillation in ablation studies.

Ours-w/oCBL decreases 2.8%‚àºsimilar-to\sim12.8% averaged accuracy compared with Ours. It validates the effectiveness of our model to balance heterogeneous forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories via category-balanced gradient propagation. Besides, Ours significantly outperforms Ours-w/oSDL by a large margin about 7.3%‚àºsimilar-to\sim18.3% averaged accuracy. It demonstrates that ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}} can effectively distill underlying inter-class relations within each task from the best old model to tackle local forgetting on old classes. From the ablation results in Tables¬†I‚àºsimilar-to\simVIII, we can conclude that the SDL module has more performance improvement than CBL module under most FCIL settings. Such large improvement is caused by the distillation of semantic relations between old and new categories explored via the SDL module. Undoubtedly, compared with the CBL module, the inter-class semantic relations play a more important role in tackling local catastrophic forgetting on hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old classes. Distilling inter-class relations between old and new models is more difficult under the real-world FCIL settings, and is more essential to balance heterogeneous forgetting speeds of hard-to-forget and easy-to-forget old categories, thus improving performance better than the CBL module. Moreover, the performance of Ours-w/oPSR decreases 0.9%‚àºsimilar-to\sim8.8% averaged accuracy. It validates the importance to address global catastrophic forgetting on old categories via the proposed proxy server.

5.5 Analysis of Anti-Forgetting on Old Categories

This subsection investigates the superiority of our LGA model to perform anti-forgetting on old categories when performing different kinds of incremental tasks (T={5,10,20}ùëá51020T=\{5,10,20\}) on CIFAR-100 [23] and MiniImageNet [45] datasets. As depicted in Figs.¬†3 and 4, we utilize F1 score and recall metrics to evaluate the anti-forgetting performance on old categories by predicting all classes instead of only the recently-seen classes. From the depicted curves in Figs.¬†3 and 4, we observe that our LGA model performs better than the conference version (i.e., GLFC [10]) to achieve anti-forgetting on old categories across different learning tasks. When compared with other class-incremental learning (CIL) methods [37, 51, 11, 12, 18], our model significantly outperforms them in terms of F1 score and recall via designing proxy server to choose the best old model for local training. It illustrates the effectiveness of our proposed LGA model to accurately identify both old and new categories instead of only the recently-seen novel classes. In the FCIL settings, the proposed LGA model is efficient to tackle local and global catastrophic forgetting on old categories.

5.6 Analysis of Heterogeneous Class Distribution

In order to discuss how heterogeneous class distribution across local clients affects performance, as presented in Table¬†IX, we conduct extensive experiments in terms of accuracy and F1 score on CIFAR-100 dataset [23]. Specifically, we consider different settings of data heterogeneity via randomly assigning {40%,50%,60%}percent40percent50percent60\{40\%,50\%,60\%\} categories from the label space of current learning task to local clients. From Table¬†IX, we conclude that the proposed LGA model achieves significant performance improvement about 3.6%‚àº6.6%similar-topercent3.6percent6.63.6\%\sim 6.6\% in terms of averaged accuracy and F1 score under different settings of heterogeneous class distributions across local clients, when compared with our conference version (i.e., GLFC [10]). It validates the effectiveness of our model to tackle local and global forgetting on old categories brought by heterogeneous class imbalance across local clients. Although the increase of data heterogeneity at local side degrades the performance of proposed model, our LGA model still achieves better performance to tackle large data heterogeneity brought by Non-IID class imbalance across local clients when compared with GLFC [10]. Table¬†IX also illustrates superiority and effectiveness of the ameliorated proxy server to tackle global catastrophic forgetting on old categories.

5.7 Analysis of Proxy Server

In this subsection, we investigate the effectiveness of proxy server to surmount global catastrophic forgetting on old classes by analyzing the performance of each proposed strategy on CIFAR-100 [23] and MiniImageNet [45] datasets, as shown in Figs.¬†6 and 7. We denote the performance (averaged accuracy, F1 score and recall) of proposed proxy server without using the selection of best old model, self-supervised prototype augmentation and noisy perturbation in latent feature space as Ours-w/oSBM, Ours-w/oSSA and Ours-w/oNPB respectively. As presented in Figs.¬†6 and 7, when compared with Ours, Ours-w/oSBM has a large performance degradation, indicating the importance of selecting the best old model to tackle global forgetting on old categories brought by Non-IID class imbalance across clients. The result degradation of Ours-w/oSSA illustrates the superiority to augment prototype images under a self-supervised manner, which is useful for the selection of old model to improve distillation gains of the category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss ‚ÑíSDsubscript‚ÑíSD\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{SD}}. Furthermore, Ours-w/oNPB shows comparable performance with Ours, since noisy perturbation is added to latent feature space for privacy preservation instead of performance improvement. As shown in Fig.¬†5, we visualize some original prototype images and their reconstructed prototype images via proxy server to better understand privacy protection of local clients.

Communication Cost: As shown in Table¬†X, the communication cost of proxy server covers only one round of 4-layer ŒìŒì\Gamma gradients (16.5MB) of prototype exemplars for each training step. Compared to the communication cost (4536.8MB) of traditional FL [31], we have 0.364% additional cost (16.5MB) since local clients transmit only one representative prototype of each new class to proxy server. Such low communication cost is acceptable in real-world applications when we have large performance improvement over existing baseline methods (see Tables¬†I‚àºsimilar-to\simVIII). Moreover, our proposed proxy server can effectively save memory storage of local clients via selecting the best old model.

5.8 Analysis of Exemplar Memory Size

To evaluate the effects of local exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥l={500,1000,1500,2000}subscript‚Ñ≥ùëô500100015002000\mathcal{M}_{l}=\{500,1000,1500,2000\} on the performance of our model, as presented in Table¬†XI, we conduct extensive experiments on CIFAR-100 [23] when setting the number of consecutive learning tasks T={5,10}ùëá510T=\{5,10\}. The experimental results presented in Table¬†XI indicate that a larger exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} can effectively improve the performance of proposed LGA model. It validates the superiority of our model to surmount local and global catastrophic forgetting on old categories when local clients use a larger memory overhead to replay more training images of old categories. Moreover, Table¬†XI illustrates that it is essential for local clients to update exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} and store old categories, after detecting new categories via task transition detection. In the FCIL settings, the exemplar memory ‚Ñ≥lsubscript‚Ñ≥ùëô\mathcal{M}_{l} at local side can effectively tackle local forgetting on old categories, further promoting the performance of global anti-forgetting.

5.9 Analysis of Varying Incremental Tasks

As shown in Table¬†XII, we conduct experiments on CIFAR-100 [23] to investigate whether varying degrees of incremental tasks can affect the performance (accuracy) of our LGA model. In Table¬†XII, the task order #1 denotes baseline task settings proposed by iCaRL [37] and GLFC [10]. As for the settings of task order #2 and task order #3, we randomly assign different classes from CIFAR-100 [23] to each incremental task. It ensures the randomness of task orders and classes within each incremental task. We can observe that the performance of our model decreases slightly for larger number of incremental tasks (T=20ùëá20T=20), but still outperforms baseline method GLFC [10] by 4.1%‚àºsimilar-to\sim6.6% averaged accuracy. Moreover, our model has little performance variance for different task orders, which shows robustness of our model to tackle different FCIL settings. From the comparisons between T=5ùëá5T=5 and T=10ùëá10T=10, we conclude that the number of classes learned in each task has negligible influence on performance, while a larger number of incremental tasks (T=20ùëá20T=20) may decrease the performance slightly.

5.10 Convergence Analysis

As shown in Fig.¬†8, we investigate the convergence analysis of our model in terms of accuracy and F1 score on CIFAR-100 [23] when setting T={5,10}ùëá510T=\{5,10\}. From the depicted curves in Fig.¬†8, we observe the proposed LGA model could efficiently converge to a stable performance after a few iteration epoches. It also validates that our LGA model could effectively learn a global class-incremental model to tackle the FCIL problem under the privacy preservation. Both local and global forgetting on old categories can be alleviated via the category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss and category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss, when the best old global model is selected via proxy server.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we focus on addressing a real-world FL challenge named Federated Class-Incremental Learning (FCIL), and propose a Local-Global Anti-forgetting (LGA) model to overcome local and global forgetting on old categories under the FCIL settings. To be specific, a category-balanced gradient-adaptive compensation loss and a category gradient-induced semantic distillation loss are designed to tackle local forgetting brought by local clients‚Äô class imbalance, by compensating heterogeneous forgetting speeds of old categories while distilling consistent class relations within different tasks. Furthermore, considering addressing global forgetting caused by Non-IID class imbalance across local clients, we develop a proxy server to reconstruct perturbed images of new categories via prototype gradient communication under privacy protection, and augment them via self-supervised prototype augmentation to select the best old global model from a global perspective. We illustrate the superiority of proposed LGA model against baseline methods via qualitative experiments on several representative datasets.

In the future, we will introduce theoretical analysis to guarantee the stable convergence of our LGA model from a theory perspective, and extend the proposed LGA model into other challenging federated learning based vision tasks such as semantic segmentation, visual tracking and object detection. Moreover, we will explore how the global server can automatically detect the number of learned classes in each incremental learning task without using human prior.
